newsitem.title: FRANCE: Australia sold Iran wheat near $150/tonne - trade.
newsitem.headline: Australia sold Iran wheat near $150/tonne - trade.

text.p: European grain traders on Friday pegged recent sales of 1.5 million tonnes of Australian wheat to Iran in the low $150s per tonne, Fob.
They said Australia was best placed to grab further business with Iran this year as it enjoyed a quality advantage over other exporters, notably the European Union.
Exporters cited selling prices ranging from $149 to $155 per tonne, Fob.
One exporter said an average level of $150 per tonne was "attractive but still correct" as it was in line with world market prices.
The salem, clinched during the past week, made Iran Australia's largest customer, bringing to 2.5 million tonnes exports to Iran in 1996/97, the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) said earlier.
AWB chairman Trevor Flugge did not disclose the price of the sale but said it was about the same level as a recent sale to Pakistan.
Australia this week sold 112,000 tonnes of Australian Standard White to Pakistan at $156.28 Fob.
"It is a very good price (for the sale to Iran) and we're very very comfortable with it," Flugge said
Traders said Australian wheat was meeting the quality standards sought by Iran, and that EU wheat might be shut out of future deals.
"Iran does not like EU wheat. It thinks its moisture content is too high. They buy EU wheat if they have nothing else," one exporter said.
Exporters also expect Argentina and Canada, which have already sold wheat to Iran during the current season, to continue competing with Australia for business.
